choices.D: Filter Threat logs by Threat Category

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - Filter Threat logs by threat [categories] that have been detected using inline cloud analysis (spyware).https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration/monitor-threat-prevention/view-threat-prevention-logs#id754cf454-0813-42e7-9b78-bd96bb07ebec

A. Filter Threat logs by Type12

Inline cloud analysis is an Advanced Threat Prevention feature that enables the detection of advanced, highly-evasive zero-day command-and-control (C2) threats and command injection and SQL injection vulnerabilities in real-time by querying the Advanced Threat Prevention cloud service12. The threats detected by inline cloud analysis are logged in the Threat logs12. By filtering these logs by Type, you can identify the threats that have been detected

D
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-0/pan-os-new-features/content-inspection-features/vuln-protection-inline-cloud-analysis
"Select MonitorLogsThreat and filter by ( category-of-threatid eq inline-cloud-exploit ) to view logs that have been analyzed using the inline cloud analysis mechanism of Advanced Threat Prevention."

questions.question_text: Which action should be taken to identify threats that have been detected by using inline cloud analysis?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABE
Service objects also have source and destination (ports) component, there is nothing like destination user, so answer should be ABE.

Selected Answer: ACE
A. Zone
C. User
E. Address

In Palo Alto PAN-OS, the three valid source or destination conditions available as Security policy qualifiers are:

A. Zone Zones define logical network segments and help enforce proper network segmentation. You can specify source and destination zones in security policies1.

C. User User conditions allow security policies to be applied based on user or group identity, enabling user-based access control1.

E. Address Address conditions specify the IP addresses, address ranges, or FQDN for the source or destination of traffic. This allows granular control over traffic flows1.

So, the correct answers to your question are A. Zone, C. User, and E. Address

Selected Answer: ACE
a c e are correct

Selected Answer: ACE
A. Zone
C. User
E. Address
These qualifiers help in creating granular security policies to control traffic based on network zones, specific users, and IP addresses or address ranges.

Should be acd 

Three valid source or destination conditions available as Security policy qualifiers are User, Application, and Zone. These qualifiers allow
you to define the match criteria for a Security policy rule based on the identity of the user, the application used, and the zone where the
traffic originates or terminates.

ACE
Zone (source, destination), Address (source, destination), User (source)
Service and Application on different tabs

questions.question_text: What are three valid source or D=destination conditions available as Security policy qualifiers? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
To see how new and modified App-IDs impact a Security policy in PAN-OS 11.x, navigate to Device > Dynamic Updates > Review Policies where you can filter by Content Version to view the impact of new or modified App-IDs introduced in a specific release, allowing you to analyze which policy rules will be affected by the updated application identification

Selected Answer: D
Device > Dynamic Updates > Review Policies

Selected Answer: D
The questions states "to review how impacts a security policy".
This is on Review Policy option

D. Device > Dynamic Updates > Review Policies

This path allows you to perform a content update policy review to see how new and modified App-IDs impact your security policy

Selected Answer: D
Device>review policy

Selected Answer: A
To see how new and modified App-IDs impact a Security policy in PAN-OS 11.x, you would follow this path:

A. Device > Dynamic Updates > Review App-IDs

This path allows you to review and analyze the impact of new and modified application identifiers (App-IDs) on your existing security policies. By accessing this section, you can determine which security policies might be affected by recent updates to the App-ID database, ensuring you can make any necessary adjustments to maintain the desired security posture.

D
Dynamic updates are in Device... is not an Object

questions.question_text: Which path in PAN-OS 11.x would you follow to see how new and modified App-IDs impact a Security policy?
What are three configurable interface types for a data-plane ethernet interface? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: L2, L3 and vWire

A. VWire (Virtual Wire) Virtual Wire interfaces allow the firewall to transparently inspect traffic without having an IP address1.

B. Layer 2 Layer 2 interfaces allow the firewall to integrate into your Layer 2 switching network1.

E. Layer 3 Layer 3 interfaces allow the firewall to perform routing1.

So, the correct answers to your question are A. VWire, B. Layer 2, and E. Layer 3

Selected Answer: ABE
Easy question

Selected Answer: ABE
Layer 3 (L3): For routing and IP addressing.
Layer 2 (L2): For switching and VLAN segmentation.
Virtual Wire (VWire): For transparent, inline traffic inspection.

ABE
You can configure Ethernet interfaces as the following types: tap, high availability (HA), log card (interface and subinterface), decrypt mirror, virtual wire (interface and subinterface), Layer 2 (interface and subinterface), Layer 3 (interface and subinterface), and aggregate Ethernet.

Layer 3

VWire
 Layer 2
I think its C not sure how B would fulfil this question it mentions a URL

Selected Answer: B
b

questions.question_text:
An administrator wants to enable access to www.paloaltonetworks.com while denying access to all other sites in the same category.

Which object should the administrator create to use as a match condition for the security policy rule that allows access to www.paloaltonetworks.com?
